title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributing to zzlongplot
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to zzlongplot
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("rgt47/zzlongplot", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to zzlongplot
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC) provides global standards clinical research data. zzlongplot package includes built-support CDISC naming conventions standards streamline clinical trial data visualization. vignette covers: - CDISC variable naming conventions - Automatic variable detection mapping - Compliance ADaM (Analysis Data Model) standards - Best practices regulatory submissions

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: CDISC defines standard variable names clinical trial analysis:

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: Let’s create dataset following CDISC conventions:
code: # Create CDISC-compliant dataset set.seed(456)  cdisc_data <- expand.grid(   USUBJID = paste0("STUDY001-001-", sprintf("%03d", 1:50)),   AVISITN = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)  # Baseline + 5 visits ) %>%   mutate(     # Subject identifier (shortened)     SUBJID = sub("STUDY001-", "", USUBJID),          # Visit information       VISIT = case_when(       AVISITN == 0 ~ "Baseline",       AVISITN == 1 ~ "Week 2",        AVISITN == 2 ~ "Week 4",       AVISITN == 3 ~ "Week 8",       AVISITN == 4 ~ "Week 12",        AVISITN == 5 ~ "Week 16"     ),          # Treatment assignments     TRT01P = rep(c("Placebo", "Drug A 5mg", "Drug A 10mg", "Drug A 20mg"),                   length.out = n()),     TRT01A = TRT01P,  # Assume planned = actual for simplicity          # Population flags     SAFFL = "Y",     FASFL = "Y",          # Analysis values - simulate depression rating scale (lower = better)     AVAL = case_when(       TRT01P == "Placebo" ~ pmax(0, rnorm(n(), mean = 20 + AVISITN * 0.5, sd = 5)),       TRT01P == "Drug A 5mg" ~ pmax(0, rnorm(n(), mean = 20 - AVISITN * 1, sd = 4.5)),       TRT01P == "Drug A 10mg" ~ pmax(0, rnorm(n(), mean = 20 - AVISITN * 2, sd = 4)),       TRT01P == "Drug A 20mg" ~ pmax(0, rnorm(n(), mean = 20 - AVISITN * 3, sd = 4))     ),          # Parameter information     PARAM = "Hamilton Depression Rating Scale Total Score",     PARAMCD = "HAMDTOT"   ) %>%   # Calculate change from baseline   group_by(USUBJID) %>%   mutate(     BASE = AVAL[AVISITN == 0],     CHG = ifelse(AVISITN == 0, NA, AVAL - BASE),     PCHG = ifelse(AVISITN == 0, NA, (AVAL - BASE) / BASE * 100)   ) %>%   ungroup() %>%   arrange(USUBJID, AVISITN)  head(cdisc_data, 10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 14 #>    USUBJID    AVISITN SUBJID VISIT TRT01P TRT01A SAFFL FASFL  AVAL PARAM PARAMCD #>    <fct>        <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <chr>  <chr>  <chr> <chr> <dbl> <chr> <chr>   #>  1 STUDY001-…       0 001-0… Base… Place… Place… Y     Y      13.3 Hami… HAMDTOT #>  2 STUDY001-…       1 001-0… Week… Drug … Drug … Y     Y      22.2 Hami… HAMDTOT #>  3 STUDY001-…       2 001-0… Week… Place… Place… Y     Y      21.6 Hami… HAMDTOT #>  4 STUDY001-…       3 001-0… Week… Drug … Drug … Y     Y      13.7 Hami… HAMDTOT #>  5 STUDY001-…       4 001-0… Week… Place… Place… Y     Y      23.5 Hami… HAMDTOT #>  6 STUDY001-…       5 001-0… Week… Drug … Drug … Y     Y      19.9 Hami… HAMDTOT #>  7 STUDY001-…       0 001-0… Base… Drug … Drug … Y     Y      21.8 Hami… HAMDTOT #>  8 STUDY001-…       1 001-0… Week… Drug … Drug … Y     Y      21.5 Hami… HAMDTOT #>  9 STUDY001-…       2 001-0… Week… Drug … Drug … Y     Y      16.1 Hami… HAMDTOT #> 10 STUDY001-…       3 001-0… Week… Drug … Drug … Y     Y      11.4 Hami… HAMDTOT #> # ℹ 3 more variables: BASE <dbl>, CHG <dbl>, PCHG <dbl>

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: package automatically recognizes CDISC variable names:
code: # Automatic CDISC recognition p1 <- lplot(   cdisc_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "USUBJID",  # Uses USUBJID (standard)   baseline_value = 0,   xlab = "Analysis Visit",   ylab = "HAMD Total Score",   title = "Depression Severity Over Time" )  print(p1)

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: CDISC often uses descriptive visit names:
code: # Using CDISC visit names p2 <- lplot(   cdisc_data,    form = AVAL ~ VISIT | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "USUBJID",   baseline_value = "Baseline",   xlab = "Study Visit",    ylab = "HAMD Total Score",   title = "Depression Severity by Visit" )  print(p2)

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: CDISC datasets typically include pre-calculated CHG values:
code: # Using pre-calculated CHG values cdisc_chg <- cdisc_data %>% filter(AVISITN > 0)  # Exclude baseline for CHG  p3 <- lplot(   cdisc_chg,   form = CHG ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "USUBJID",    baseline_value = 1,  # First post-baseline visit   xlab = "Analysis Visit",   ylab = "Change from Baseline (HAMD)",   title = "Change in Depression Severity" )  print(p3)

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: package can automatically detect likely CDISC variables:
code: # Auto-detect CDISC variables (when implemented) suggestions <- suggest_clinical_vars(cdisc_data) print(suggestions)  #> CDISC Variables Detected: #> ======================== #> Subject ID: USUBJID (primary), SUBJID (alternate)   #> Visit: AVISITN (numeric), VISIT (character) #> Analysis Value: AVAL #> Change from Baseline: CHG  #> Treatment: TRT01P (planned), TRT01A (actual) #> Population Flags: SAFFL, FASFL #> #> Suggested Formula: AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P #> Cluster Variable: USUBJID #> Baseline Visit: AVISITN = 0

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
code: # Check CDISC compliance (when implemented) compliance <- validate_cdisc_data(cdisc_data) print(compliance)  #> CDISC Compliance Report: #> ======================= #> ✓ Subject identifiers present (USUBJID, SUBJID) #> ✓ Visit variables present (AVISITN, VISIT)  #> ✓ Analysis value present (AVAL) #> ✓ Treatment variable present (TRT01P) #> ✓ Population flags present (SAFFL, FASFL) #> ✓ Change from baseline calculated (CHG) #> ! Missing PCHG (percent change from baseline) #>  #> Overall Compliance: 95%

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: ADaM CDISC standard analysis datasets. Key requirements include:

previous_headings: ADaM Standards Compliance > Analysis Data Model (ADaM)
title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: Every ADaM dataset : - USUBJID: Unique subject identifier - SUBJID: Subject identifier within study - STUDYID: Study identifier - SITEID: Site identifier
code: # Add ADaM required variables cdisc_adam <- cdisc_data %>%   mutate(     STUDYID = "STUDY001",     SITEID = substr(SUBJID, 1, 3)  # Extract site from SUBJID   )  # Verify required variables required_vars <- c("USUBJID", "SUBJID", "STUDYID") cat("Required ADaM variables present:",      all(required_vars %in% names(cdisc_adam)), "\n") #> Required ADaM variables present: TRUE

previous_headings: ADaM Standards Compliance > Analysis Data Model (ADaM)
title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: ADaM datasets include population analysis flags:
code: # Population-specific analysis fasfl_data <- cdisc_adam %>% filter(FASFL == "Y")  p4 <- lplot(   fasfl_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,    cluster_var = "USUBJID",   baseline_value = 0,   clinical_mode = TRUE,   title = "Primary Analysis (Full Analysis Set)",   subtitle = "FASFL = 'Y' Population" )  print(p4)

previous_headings: ADaM Standards Compliance > Analysis Data Model (ADaM)
title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: ADaM requires traceability source data:
code: # Add traceability variables (example) cdisc_trace <- cdisc_adam %>%   mutate(     # Source dataset references     SRCDOM = "QS",        # Source domain (Questionnaires)     SRCVAR = "QSSTRESN",  # Source variable     SRCSEQ = row_number() # Source sequence   )

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: Use CDISC controlled terminology:
code: # CDISC controlled terminology for treatments treatment_mapping <- c(   "Placebo" = "Placebo",   "Drug A 5mg" = "COMPOUND-A 5 MG",    "Drug A 10mg" = "COMPOUND-A 10 MG",   "Drug A 20mg" = "COMPOUND-A 20 MG" )  cdisc_terminology <- cdisc_adam %>%   mutate(     TRT01P_STD = recode(TRT01P, !!!treatment_mapping)   )  p5 <- lplot(   cdisc_terminology,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P_STD,   cluster_var = "USUBJID",   baseline_value = 0,   clinical_mode = TRUE,   title = "Efficacy Analysis - Standard Terminology" )  print(p5)

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: CDISC requires explicit missing data handling:
code: # Add some missing data patterns cdisc_missing <- cdisc_adam %>%   mutate(     # Simulate missing data (dropout pattern)     AVAL = ifelse(       AVISITN >= 3 & runif(n()) < 0.1 * (AVISITN - 2),        NA,        AVAL     )   )  # Plot showing missing data impact p6 <- lplot(   cdisc_missing,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "USUBJID",    baseline_value = 0,   clinical_mode = TRUE,   title = "Analysis with Missing Data",   subtitle = "Observed Cases Only" )  print(p6)

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: Always use CDISC standard variable names:
code: # Good: CDISC standard names good_plot <- lplot(   cdisc_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "USUBJID",   baseline_value = 0 )  # Avoid: Non-standard names # bad_plot <- lplot(data, score ~ week | treatment, cluster_var = "id")

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: Use analysis population flags appropriately:
code: # Safety population analysis safety_data <- cdisc_adam %>% filter(SAFFL == "Y")  # Full analysis set fas_data <- cdisc_adam %>% filter(FASFL == "Y")   cat("Safety Population N =", length(unique(safety_data$USUBJID)), "\n") #> Safety Population N = 50 cat("Full Analysis Set N =", length(unique(fas_data$USUBJID)), "\n") #> Full Analysis Set N = 50

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: Include standard parameter information:
code: # Check parameter consistency params <- cdisc_data %>%   select(PARAM, PARAMCD) %>%   distinct()  print(params) #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   PARAM                                        PARAMCD #>   <chr>                                        <chr>   #> 1 Hamilton Depression Rating Scale Total Score HAMDTOT  # Use parameter in titles p7 <- lplot(   cdisc_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "USUBJID",   baseline_value = 0,   clinical_mode = TRUE,   title = paste("Analysis of", unique(cdisc_data$PARAM)) )  print(p7)

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: Clearly define baseline CDISC terms:
code: # Baseline should be clearly identified baseline_info <- cdisc_data %>%   filter(AVISITN == 0) %>%   summarise(     n_subjects = n_distinct(USUBJID),     baseline_visit = unique(VISIT)   )  cat("Baseline Definition:", baseline_info$baseline_visit, "\n") #> Baseline Definition: Baseline cat("Subjects with Baseline:", baseline_info$n_subjects, "\n") #> Subjects with Baseline: 50

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
code: # Check for CDISC compliance issues qc_results <- cdisc_data %>%   summarise(     # Check for missing required variables     has_usubjid = "USUBJID" %in% names(.),     has_avisitn = "AVISITN" %in% names(.),     has_aval = "AVAL" %in% names(.),     has_trt01p = "TRT01P" %in% names(.),          # Check for data completeness     missing_aval = sum(is.na(AVAL)),     missing_chg = sum(is.na(CHG)),          # Check visit structure     baseline_visits = sum(AVISITN == 0),     max_visit = max(AVISITN, na.rm = TRUE)   )  print(qc_results) #> # A tibble: 1 × 8 #>   has_usubjid has_avisitn has_aval has_trt01p missing_aval missing_chg #>   <lgl>       <lgl>       <lgl>    <lgl>             <int>       <int> #> 1 TRUE        TRUE        TRUE     TRUE                  0          50 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: baseline_visits <int>, max_visit <dbl>

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
code: # Regulatory submission checklist checklist <- list(   "USUBJID present" = "USUBJID" %in% names(cdisc_data),   "AVISITN standardized" = is.numeric(cdisc_data$AVISITN),   "Treatment coded" = "TRT01P" %in% names(cdisc_data),     "Population flags" = all(c("SAFFL", "FASFL") %in% names(cdisc_data)),   "CHG calculated" = "CHG" %in% names(cdisc_data),   "Parameters defined" = "PARAM" %in% names(cdisc_data) )  # Print checklist for(item in names(checklist)) {   status <- ifelse(checklist[[item]], "✓", "✗")   cat(status, item, "\n") } #> ✓ USUBJID present  #> ✓ AVISITN standardized  #> ✓ Treatment coded  #> ✓ Population flags  #> ✓ CHG calculated  #> ✓ Parameters defined

title: CDISC Compliance and Standards
text: zzlongplot package supports CDISC compliance : Automatic Recognition: Built-support CDISC variable names ADaM Standards: Compliance Analysis Data Model requirements Quality Controls: Data validation compliance checking Regulatory Ready: Professional output suitable submissions Key CDISC features: - Standard variable name recognition (USUBJID, AVISITN, AVAL, TRT01P) - Automatic baseline identification change calculation - Population flag support (SAFFL, FASFL) - Parameter standardization (PARAM, PARAMCD) - Missing data handling patterns implementation examples, see Clinical Trials vignette.

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: zzlongplot package provides specialized functionality clinical trial data visualization, built-support CDISC standards, regulatory requirements, common clinical trial analysis patterns. vignette demonstrates use clinical-specific features.

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: Clinical trial data typically follows CDISC (Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium) standards specific variable naming conventions: SUBJID: Subject identifier AVISITN: Analysis visit number AVAL: Analysis value (primary endpoint) CHG: Change baseline TRT01P: Planned treatment SAFFL: Safety population flag Let’s create realistic clinical trial dataset:
code: # Simulate clinical trial data set.seed(123) n_subjects <- 60 n_visits <- 5  clinical_data <- expand.grid(   SUBJID = paste0("001-", sprintf("%03d", 1:n_subjects)),   AVISITN = 0:4  # Baseline + 4 follow-up visits ) %>%   mutate(     TRT01P = rep(c("Placebo", "Drug A 10mg", "Drug A 20mg"), length.out = n()),     # Simulate efficacy score (higher = better)     AVAL = case_when(       TRT01P == "Placebo" ~ rnorm(n(), mean = 45 - AVISITN * 0.5, sd = 8),       TRT01P == "Drug A 10mg" ~ rnorm(n(), mean = 45 - AVISITN * 1.5, sd = 7),       TRT01P == "Drug A 20mg" ~ rnorm(n(), mean = 45 - AVISITN * 2.5, sd = 6)     ),     VISITN = AVISITN + 1,     VISIT = case_when(       AVISITN == 0 ~ "Baseline",       AVISITN == 1 ~ "Week 4",       AVISITN == 2 ~ "Week 8",        AVISITN == 3 ~ "Week 12",       AVISITN == 4 ~ "Week 16"     )   ) %>%   arrange(SUBJID, AVISITN)  head(clinical_data) #>    SUBJID AVISITN      TRT01P     AVAL VISITN    VISIT #> 1 001-001       0     Placebo 40.51619      1 Baseline #> 2 001-001       1     Placebo 47.53712      2   Week 4 #> 3 001-001       2     Placebo 44.94117      3   Week 8 #> 4 001-001       3     Placebo 34.99339      4  Week 12 #> 5 001-001       4     Placebo 36.69102      5  Week 16 #> 6 001-002       0 Drug A 10mg 39.73118      1 Baseline

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: simplest way create clinical trial visualization:
code: # Basic clinical plot with observed values p1 <- lplot(   clinical_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "SUBJID",   baseline_value = 0,   xlab = "Visit Number",   ylab = "Efficacy Score",    title = "Efficacy Over Time by Treatment Group" )  print(p1)

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: Clinical trials often require observed values change baseline:
code: # Both observed and change plots p2 <- lplot(   clinical_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "SUBJID",    baseline_value = 0,   plot_type = "both",   xlab = "Visit Number",   ylab = "Efficacy Score",   ylab2 = "Change from Baseline",   title = "Observed Efficacy",   title2 = "Change from Baseline" )  print(p2)

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: clinical_mode = TRUE parameter automatically applies clinical trial best practices:  Clinical mode automatically enables: - 95% confidence intervals instead standard error - Sample size annotations timepoint - Clinical color scheme (placebo grey, treatments distinct colors) - Professional theme suitable regulatory submissions
code: # Clinical mode with all clinical defaults p3 <- lplot(   clinical_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "SUBJID",   baseline_value = 0,   clinical_mode = TRUE,   plot_type = "both",   title = "Clinical Trial Results",   title2 = "Change from Baseline" )  print(p3)

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: can also enable clinical features individually:
code: # Individual clinical features p4 <- lplot(   clinical_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "SUBJID",   baseline_value = 0,   treatment_colors = "standard",     # Clinical color scheme   confidence_interval = 0.95,        # 95% CI   show_sample_sizes = TRUE,          # Show N at each timepoint   error_type = "bar",               # Error bars (common in clinical)   title = "Efficacy Analysis - Individual Features" )  print(p4)

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: Clinical trials often use visit names instead numbers:
code: # Using categorical visit names p5 <- lplot(   clinical_data,   form = AVAL ~ VISIT | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "SUBJID",   baseline_value = "Baseline",   clinical_mode = TRUE,   plot_type = "both",   xlab = "Study Visit",   title = "Efficacy by Visit",   title2 = "Change from Baseline" )  print(p5)

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: Real clinical trials visit timing variations. Handle visit windows:
code: # Add some visit timing variation clinical_data_windows <- clinical_data %>%   mutate(     VISIT_DAY = case_when(       AVISITN == 0 ~ 0,       AVISITN == 1 ~ round(rnorm(n(), 28, 3)),    # Target day 28 ± 3       AVISITN == 2 ~ round(rnorm(n(), 56, 4)),    # Target day 56 ± 4         AVISITN == 3 ~ round(rnorm(n(), 84, 5)),    # Target day 84 ± 5       AVISITN == 4 ~ round(rnorm(n(), 112, 6))    # Target day 112 ± 6     )   )  # Plot with visit windows (when this feature is implemented) p6 <- lplot(   clinical_data_windows,   form = AVAL ~ VISIT_DAY | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "SUBJID",   baseline_value = 0,   clinical_mode = TRUE,   # visit_windows = list(   #   "Month 1" = c(21, 35),   #   "Month 2" = c(49, 63),   #   "Month 3" = c(77, 91),   #   "Month 4" = c(105, 119)   # ),   xlab = "Study Day",   title = "Efficacy Over Time (Study Days)" ) #> Warning: There were 4 warnings in `dplyr::mutate()`. #> The first warning was: #> ℹ In argument: `bound_lower = if (...) NULL`. #> Caused by warning in `stats::qt()`: #> ! NaNs produced #> ℹ Run `dplyr::last_dplyr_warnings()` to see the 3 remaining warnings.  print(p6)

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: Create plots suitable FDA submissions:
code: # FDA regulatory theme (when implemented) p7 <- lplot(   clinical_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "SUBJID",   baseline_value = 0,   theme = "fda",   plot_type = "both",   title = "Figure 1.1: Primary Efficacy Endpoint",   title2 = "Figure 1.2: Change from Baseline",   caption = "ITT Population, LOCF imputation" )  print(p7)

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
code: # Save in regulatory-friendly format save_clinical_plot(p7,   filename = "Figure_1_1_Primary_Efficacy.png",   width = 10, height = 6, dpi = 300,   title = "Figure 1.1",   footnote = "ITT Population; LOCF imputation applied" )

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: package can automatically suggest appropriate formulas clinical data:
code: # Auto-detect CDISC variables and suggest formula suggestions <- suggest_clinical_vars(clinical_data) print(suggestions) #> Suggested formula: AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P   #> Cluster variable: SUBJID detected #> Baseline: AVISITN = 0

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: Get standard clinical color palettes:
code: # Get clinical color palette colors <- clinical_colors(type = "treatment", n = 3) print(colors) #> [1] "#7F7F7F" "#1F77B4" "#D62728"  # Grey, Blue, Red  # Use with custom styling p8 <- lplot(   clinical_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "SUBJID",   baseline_value = 0,   color_palette = colors )

what: 1. Always Show Both Observed and Change
title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: clinical protocols require perspectives:
code: # Best practice: Show both plots lplot(clinical_data, AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,        cluster_var = "SUBJID", baseline_value = 0,       plot_type = "both", clinical_mode = TRUE)

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: 95% confidence intervals standard clinical trials:
code: # Best practice: 95% confidence intervals lplot(clinical_data, AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,       cluster_var = "SUBJID", baseline_value = 0,        confidence_interval = 0.95)

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: Show sample sizes indicate data completeness:
code: # Best practice: Show sample sizes lplot(clinical_data, AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,       cluster_var = "SUBJID", baseline_value = 0,       show_sample_sizes = TRUE, clinical_mode = TRUE)

code: # Best practice: Professional themes lplot(clinical_data, AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,       cluster_var = "SUBJID", baseline_value = 0,       theme = "fda", clinical_mode = TRUE)

title: Clinical Trials with zzlongplot
text: zzlongplot package provides comprehensive support clinical trial data visualization, basic efficacy plots regulatory-ready submissions. clinical mode feature enables best practices single parameter, individual features allow custom requirements. Key clinical features include: - CDISC variable recognition - Clinical color schemes themes - Confidence intervals sample size annotations - Visit window handling - Regulatory output formats - Professional themes submissions examples advanced features, see CDISC Compliance vignette.

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Longitudinal data visualization presents unique challenges require specialized plotting solutions. zzlongplot package addresses challenges providing comprehensive, flexible framework creating publication-quality visualizations longitudinal data R. Whether ’re conducting clinical trials, educational assessments, research repeated measurements time, zzlongplot offers intuitive functions streamline creation observed value plots change--baseline visualizations.

what: The Challenge of Longitudinal Data Visualization
title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Researchers working longitudinal data typically need answer two fundamental questions: measurements change time? changes differ groups conditions? address questions effectively, visualizations must: Display observed values time point Show changes relative baseline measures Represent uncertainty appropriately Allow comparisons across different groups Accommodate continuous time points (e.g., days, years) categorical time points (e.g., “baseline”, “month1”, “month2”) Support faceting explore interactions additional variables base R graphics packages like ggplot2 provide powerful visualization capabilities, creating consistent, publication-ready longitudinal plots often requires extensive custom code. zzlongplot fills gap offering specialized suite functions designed specifically longitudinal data visualization.

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: zzlongplot package offers several advantages researchers working longitudinal data:

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Works continuous categorical time variables Handles balanced unbalanced designs Supports grouped data comparing different conditions Allows flexible specification baseline values

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Generate observed value plots showing raw measurements time Create change--baseline plots highlighting differences starting points Combine plot types side--side comprehensive reporting Customize axis labels, titles, plot elements

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Visualize uncertainty either error bars confidence ribbons Automatically calculate display standard errors Handle within-subject clustering accurate error estimation

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: zzlongplot employs formula-based interface similar used statistical modeling functions, making intuitive R users: consistent syntax provides familiar experience offering substantial flexibility.
code: # Basic usage lplot(data, y ~ x | group)  # With faceting lplot(data, y ~ x | group, facet_form = facet_y ~ facet_x)

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Built-support colorblind-friendly palettes Consistent, publication-ready styling defaults Easy customization specific journal requirements

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: zzlongplot package consists several core functions: lplot(): main user-facing function creates longitudinal plots parse_formula(): Processes formula notation specifies plotting variables compute_stats(): Calculates summary statistics different groups time points generate_plot(): Creates actual visualizations using ggplot2 get_colorblind_palette(): Provides accessible color schemes plots functions work together deliver streamlined workflow creating sophisticated longitudinal visualizations minimal code.

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Let’s begin creating sample dataset longitudinal measurements ’ll use throughout vignette.

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: First, ’ll create dataset continuous time points: Next, let’s create dataset categorical time points:
code: # Set seed for reproducibility set.seed(123)  # Create sample data with continuous time points continuous_data <- data.frame(   subject_id = rep(1:50, each = 4),   visit_time = rep(c(0, 4, 8, 12), times = 50),  # Weeks from baseline   outcome = NA,  # Will fill this with simulated data   group = rep(c("Treatment", "Placebo"), each = 2, length.out = 200) )  # Generate outcome data with treatment effect increasing over time for (subject in unique(continuous_data$subject_id)) {   subject_rows <- which(continuous_data$subject_id == subject)   baseline <- 50 + rnorm(1, 0, 5)  # Baseline value with some variation      is_treatment <- continuous_data$group[subject_rows[1]] == "Treatment"      # Treatment effect increases over time, placebo has minimal effect   effect_size <- if (is_treatment) c(0, 3, 7, 12) else c(0, 1, 1.5, 2)      # Add individual trajectory with some random noise   continuous_data$outcome[subject_rows] <- baseline + effect_size + rnorm(4, 0, 3) }  # Look at the first few rows of our data head(continuous_data, 8) #>   subject_id visit_time  outcome     group #> 1          1          0 46.50709 Treatment #> 2          1          4 54.87375 Treatment #> 3          1          8 54.40915   Placebo #> 4          1         12 59.58548   Placebo #> 5          2          0 59.95807 Treatment #> 6          2          4 57.78014 Treatment #> 7          2          8 63.51477   Placebo #> 8          2         12 69.23834   Placebo # Create sample data with categorical time points categorical_data <- data.frame(   subject_id = rep(1:50, each = 4),   visit = rep(c("Baseline", "Month1", "Month3", "Month6"), times = 50),   score = NA,  # Will fill this with simulated data   treatment = rep(c("Drug A", "Drug B", "Placebo"), length.out = 50, each = 4),   site = rep(c("Site 1", "Site 2"), length.out = 200)  # For faceting examples )  # Generate score data with different treatment effects for (subject in unique(categorical_data$subject_id)) {   subject_rows <- which(categorical_data$subject_id == subject)   baseline <- 25 + rnorm(1, 0, 3)  # Baseline value      # Different effects for different treatments   treatment_type <- categorical_data$treatment[subject_rows[1]]      if (treatment_type == "Drug A") {     effect_size <- c(0, 5, 8, 10)  # Strong effect   } else if (treatment_type == "Drug B") {     effect_size <- c(0, 4, 5, 7)   # Moderate effect   } else {     effect_size <- c(0, 2, 2, 3)   # Weak effect (placebo)   }      # Add individual trajectory with some random noise   categorical_data$score[subject_rows] <- baseline + effect_size + rnorm(4, 0, 2) }  # Look at the first few rows of our data head(categorical_data, 8) #>   subject_id    visit    score treatment   site #> 1          1 Baseline 22.74944    Drug A Site 1 #> 2          1   Month1 28.18536    Drug A Site 2 #> 3          1   Month3 32.05418    Drug A Site 1 #> 4          1   Month6 37.07021    Drug A Site 2 #> 5          2 Baseline 26.89590    Drug B Site 1 #> 6          2   Month1 29.99581    Drug B Site 2 #> 7          2   Month3 29.50702    Drug B Site 1 #> 8          2   Month6 28.66850    Drug B Site 2

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Let’s start basic usage zzlongplot: creating simple plot outcome time.  example, ’ve used simple formula outcome ~ visit_time specify want plot outcome variable y-axis visit time x-axis. Since haven’t specified grouping variable, subjects plotted together.
code: # Basic plot showing outcome over time lplot(continuous_data,        form = outcome ~ visit_time,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = 0,       title = "Outcome Over Time",       xlab = "Weeks",       ylab = "Outcome Measure")

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Now, let’s use formula syntax add grouping treatment:  formula outcome ~ visit_time | group tells zzlongplot : - Plot outcome y-axis - Use visit_time x-axis - Group color lines “group” variable makes easy compare trajectories different treatment groups.
code: # Plot with grouping by treatment lplot(continuous_data,        form = outcome ~ visit_time | group,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = 0,       title = "Treatment Effect Over Time",       xlab = "Weeks",       ylab = "Outcome Measure")

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: One key features zzlongplot ability visualize changes baseline. Let’s create plot showing observed values changes:  setting plot_type = "", get two side--side plots: 1. left plot shows observed values 2. right plot shows change baseline makes easy see absolute measurements relative changes one figure.
code: # Plot both observed values and change from baseline lplot(continuous_data,        form = outcome ~ visit_time | group,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = 0,       plot_type = "both",       title = "Observed Outcomes",       title2 = "Change from Baseline",       xlab = "Weeks",       ylab = "Outcome Measure",       ylab2 = "Change in Outcome")

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Now let’s demonstrate zzlongplot handles categorical time points using second dataset:  Notice ’ve specified baseline_value = "Baseline" indicate baseline level categorical variable. formula syntax remains regardless whether x-variable continuous categorical.
code: # Plot with categorical time points lplot(categorical_data,        form = score ~ visit | treatment,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = "Baseline",       title = "Treatment Comparison",       xlab = "Visit",       ylab = "Score")

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: zzlongplot supports faceting examine effects might differ across another variable. Let’s add faceting site:  facet_form = ~ site syntax tells zzlongplot create separate panels level “site” variable. allows easy comparison treatment effects across different sites.
code: # Plot with faceting by site lplot(categorical_data,        form = score ~ visit | treatment,       facet_form = ~ site,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = "Baseline",       title = "Treatment Comparison by Site",       xlab = "Visit",       ylab = "Score")

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: default, zzlongplot uses error bars represent standard error. can switch confidence bands using error_type parameter:  Confidence bands can sometimes provide cleaner visualization, especially multiple groups compared.
code: # Using confidence bands instead of error bars lplot(categorical_data,        form = score ~ visit | treatment,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = "Baseline",       error_type = "band",       title = "Treatment Comparison with Confidence Bands",       xlab = "Visit",       ylab = "Score")

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: zzlongplot includes support custom color palettes. Let’s define colorblind-friendly palette:  Note: full version zzlongplot package includes get_colorblind_palette() function automatically generates appropriate color schemes, ’re using manual definition demonstration purposes. ensures visualizations accessible readers color vision deficiencies.
code: # Define a colorblind-friendly palette manually # These colors are based on the ColorBrewer "Dark2" palette custom_colors <- c("#1B9E77", "#D95F02", "#7570B3")  # Apply custom colors to the plot lplot(categorical_data,        form = score ~ visit | treatment,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = "Baseline",       color_palette = custom_colors,       title = "Treatment Comparison with Custom Colors",       xlab = "Visit",       ylab = "Score")

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Let’s explore advanced use cases demonstrate flexibility zzlongplot.

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: formula interface supports multiple grouping variables combining +:  formula score ~ visit | treatment + gender creates groups combination treatment gender, allowing us examine potential interactions variables.
code: # First, add a secondary grouping variable to our data categorical_data$gender <- rep(c("Female", "Male"), length.out = nrow(categorical_data))  # Plot with two grouping variables lplot(categorical_data,        form = score ~ visit | treatment + gender,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = "Baseline",       title = "Treatment by Gender Interaction",       xlab = "Visit",       ylab = "Score")

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: can also use formulas create complex faceting arrangements:  facet_form = age_group ~ site syntax creates grid panels age groups rows sites columns, allowing comprehensive comparison across multiple dimensions.
code: # Add another variable for faceting categorical_data$age_group <- rep(c("Young", "Middle", "Elder"), length.out = nrow(categorical_data))  # Create a plot with multi-dimensional faceting lplot(categorical_data,        form = score ~ visit | treatment,       facet_form = age_group ~ site,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = "Baseline",       title = "Treatment Effects Across Age Groups and Sites",       xlab = "Visit",       ylab = "Score")

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Sometimes might want use non-standard time point baseline. zzlongplot makes easy:  setting baseline_value = 4, ’re using Week 4 reference point rather usual Week 0. flexibility allows various analysis approaches, examining later measurements compare mid-study values.
code: # Using a non-zero time point as baseline for continuous data lplot(continuous_data,        form = outcome ~ visit_time | group,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = 4,  # Using week 4 as baseline instead of week 0       plot_type = "both",       title = "Outcomes (Week 4 as Baseline)",       title2 = "Change from Week 4",       xlab = "Weeks",       ylab = "Outcome Measure",       ylab2 = "Change from Week 4")

what: Clinical Trial Example with Responder Analysis
title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: Let’s demonstrate complex example typical clinical trials, might want analyze raw scores responder status:  example demonstrates zzlongplot can integrated comprehensive analysis workflow, combining standard longitudinal visualizations custom plots derived endpoints.
code: # Create a clinical trial dataset clinical_data <- data.frame(   subject_id = rep(1:60, each = 5),   visit_week = rep(c(0, 2, 4, 8, 12), times = 60),   pain_score = NA,   responder = NA,  # Will define responders as those with ≥30% improvement   treatment = rep(c("Active", "Control"), each = 5, length.out = 300),   site = rep(c("Site A", "Site B", "Site C"), length.out = 300) )  # Generate pain scores (0-10 scale, higher = worse pain) for (subject in unique(clinical_data$subject_id)) {   subject_rows <- which(clinical_data$subject_id == subject)   baseline <- 7 + rnorm(1, 0, 1)  # Most patients start with severe pain      # Different effects for different treatments   is_active <- clinical_data$treatment[subject_rows[1]] == "Active"      # Effect sizes (pain reduction)   if (is_active) {     effect_size <- c(0, 1, 2, 3, 3.5)  # Stronger pain reduction   } else {     effect_size <- c(0, 0.5, 1, 1.2, 1.5)  # Weaker pain reduction   }      # Add individual trajectory with some random noise   clinical_data$pain_score[subject_rows] <- pmax(0, baseline - effect_size + rnorm(5, 0, 1)) }  # Calculate responder status (≥30% improvement from baseline) clinical_data <- clinical_data %>%   group_by(subject_id) %>%   mutate(     baseline_score = pain_score[visit_week == 0],     pct_improvement = (baseline_score - pain_score) / baseline_score * 100,     responder = ifelse(pct_improvement >= 30, "Responder", "Non-responder")   ) %>%   ungroup()  # Plot pain scores over time pain_plot <- lplot(clinical_data,        form = pain_score ~ visit_week | treatment,       cluster_var = "subject_id",       baseline_value = 0,       title = "Pain Score Over Time",       xlab = "Week",       ylab = "Pain Score (0-10)")  # Calculate responder percentages responder_data <- clinical_data %>%   dplyr::filter(visit_week > 0) %>%  # Exclude baseline   group_by(treatment, visit_week) %>%   summarize(     n_subjects = n(),     n_responders = sum(responder == "Responder"),     pct_responders = n_responders / n_subjects * 100,     .groups = "drop"   )  # Create a custom plot for responder rates responder_plot <- ggplot(responder_data, aes(x = visit_week, y = pct_responders, color = treatment, group = treatment)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point(size = 3) +   labs(title = "Responder Rates (≥30% Improvement)",        x = "Week",        y = "Percent of Responders",        color = "Treatment") +   theme_bw() +   theme(legend.position = "bottom")  # Combine the plots using patchwork pain_plot + responder_plot + patchwork::plot_layout(ncol = 2)

title: zzlongplot: A Flexible Framework for Longitudinal Data Visualization
text: using zzlongplot research, consider best practices: Choose meaningful baselines: choice baseline can significantly impact interpretation change values. Consider observed change plots: Observed values show absolute measurements, change plots highlight relative differences. provide valuable insights. Use appropriate error representation: Error bars work well categorical x-variables levels, confidence bands may preferable continuous x-variables comparing many groups. Apply colorblind-friendly palettes: Ensure visualizations accessible readers using appropriate color palettes, ones ColorBrewer package (e.g., “Dark2” categorical data). Leverage faceting judiciously: Faceting can reveal important patterns can also make plots complex. Use comparing across important categorical variables. Provide clear labels titles: Ensure plots informative axis labels, titles, legends guide interpretation.

what: Longitudinal Plotting with Clinical Trials Support
title: Longitudinal Plotting with Clinical Trials Support
text: zzlongplot R package flexible, dynamic visualization observed change values longitudinal datasets. Designed continuous categorical variables, zzlongplot simplifies creation grouped faceted plots, offering customization options axes, titles, error representations. package particularly useful analyzing longitudinal clinical trial data, repeated measures, data time- visit-dependent structure.

title: Longitudinal Plotting with Clinical Trials Support
text: Dynamic Plotting: Automatically adapts plots continuous categorical x-axis variables. Observed Change Plots: Easily visualize observed values changes relative baseline (baseline_value). Grouping Faceting: Support multiple grouping variables faceting stratified visualizations. Custom Error Representation: Choose error bars ribbons represent uncertainty. Combining Plots: Use patchwork package display observed change plots side--side. Formula Interface: Seamless integration formulas specifying variables (y ~ x | group).

title: Longitudinal Plotting with Clinical Trials Support
text: CDISC Compliance: Automatic recognition standard CDISC variable names (AVAL, AVISITN, TRT01P, etc.) Clinical Themes: FDA regulatory-ready plot styling professional themes Treatment Styling: Predefined color schemes placebo vs. active treatment visualization Visit Windows: Handle visit timing variations common clinical trials Clinical Statistics: 95% confidence intervals, sample size annotations, missing data handling Regulatory Output: Export plots formats suitable regulatory submissions

title: Longitudinal Plotting with Clinical Trials Support

code: # Install devtools if not already installed install.packages("devtools")  # Install zzlongplot from GitHub devtools::install_github("your-username/zzlongplot")

title: Longitudinal Plotting with Clinical Trials Support
text: ’s get started zzlongplot:

title: Longitudinal Plotting with Clinical Trials Support
code: # Load the required libraries library(zzlongplot) library(ggplot2)  # Example dataset df <- data.frame(   subject_id = rep(1:10, each = 3),   visit = rep(c(0, 1, 2), times = 10),   measure = rnorm(30, mean = 50, sd = 10),   group = rep(c("A", "B"), length.out = 30) )  # Generate the plot plot <- lplot(   df,    form = measure ~ visit | group,    cluster_var = "subject_id",   baseline_value = 0,    xlab = "Visit",    ylab = "Measure",    title = "Observed Measures Over Time" ) print(plot)

title: Longitudinal Plotting with Clinical Trials Support
code: # Example dataset with categorical x-axis df <- data.frame(   subject_id = rep(1:10, each = 3),   visit = rep(c("baseline", "month1", "month2"), times = 10),   measure = rnorm(30, mean = 50, sd = 10),   group = rep(c("A", "B"), length.out = 30) )  # Generate the plot plot <- lplot(   df,    form = measure ~ visit | group,    cluster_var = "subject_id",   baseline_value = "baseline",    xlab = "Visit",    ylab = "Measure",    title = "Observed Measures Over Time" ) print(plot)

what: Example 3: Clinical Trial with CDISC Variables 🏥
title: Longitudinal Plotting with Clinical Trials Support
code: # Clinical trial data with CDISC variable names clinical_data <- data.frame(   SUBJID = rep(paste0("001-", sprintf("%03d", 1:20)), each = 4),   AVISITN = rep(c(0, 4, 8, 12), times = 20),  # Visit weeks   AVAL = rnorm(80, mean = c(45, 42, 38, 35), sd = 8),  # Efficacy score   TRT01P = rep(c("Placebo", "Drug A", "Drug B"), length.out = 80),   CHG = NA  # Will be calculated automatically )  # Clinical mode - automatically handles CDISC variables and styling plot_clinical <- lplot(   clinical_data,   form = AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,   cluster_var = "SUBJID",   baseline_value = 0,   clinical_mode = TRUE,           # Enables clinical defaults   treatment_colors = "standard",  # Standard clinical colors   confidence_interval = 0.95,     # 95% CI instead of SE   show_sample_sizes = TRUE,       # Show N at each timepoint   plot_type = "both",            # Both observed and change plots   title = "Efficacy Over Time",   title2 = "Change from Baseline" ) print(plot_clinical)

text: Computes summary statistics observed change values longitudinal data, supporting continuous categorical x-axis variables.

title: Compute Summary Statistics for Longitudinal Data — compute_stats
code: compute_stats(   df,   x_var,   y_var,   group_var,   cluster_var,   baseline_value,   confidence_interval = NULL,   show_sample_sizes = FALSE,   statistical_tests = FALSE )

title: Compute Summary Statistics for Longitudinal Data — compute_stats
text: df data frame containing data plotted. x_var independent variable (x-axis) name. y_var dependent variable (y-axis) name. group_var Grouping variable data (optional). cluster_var Cluster variable within-subject grouping (subject ID). baseline_value Baseline value calculating changes. confidence_interval Numeric. Confidence level (e.g., 0.95 95% CI). specified, calculates confidence intervals instead standard error. show_sample_sizes Logical. TRUE, includes sample sizes output. statistical_tests Logical. TRUE, performs statistical comparisons.

title: Compute Summary Statistics for Longitudinal Data — compute_stats
text: data frame containing computed statistics columns: Original x group variables mean_value: Mean y values change_mean: Mean change baseline sample_size: Number observations standard_deviation: Standard deviation y values change_sd: Standard deviation change values standard_error: Standard error mean change_se: Standard error change mean bound_lower/bound_upper: Lower/upper bounds error bars (mean ± SE) bound_lower_change/bound_upper_change: Bounds change value error bars group: Factor combining grouping variables is_continuous: Boolean indicating x continuous

title: Compute Summary Statistics for Longitudinal Data — compute_stats
code: df <- data.frame(   subject_id = rep(1:10, each = 3),   visit = rep(c(0, 1, 2), times = 10),   measure = rnorm(30, mean = 50, sd = 10),   group = rep(c("A", "B"), length.out = 30) ) # Compute statistics with visit as x variable, measure as y variable, # grouped by treatment group, with subject_id as the cluster variable stats <- compute_stats(df, "visit", "measure", "group", "subject_id", 0) head(stats) #> # A tibble: 6 × 15 #>   group visit mean_value change_mean sample_size standard_deviation change_sd #>   <fct> <dbl>      <dbl>       <dbl>       <int>              <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 A         0       50.9        0              5               7.85      0    #> 2 A         1       44.0      -13.6            5               6.93     13.0  #> 3 A         2       42.7       -8.15           5              15.2      17.4  #> 4 B         0       57.6        0              5               8.68      0    #> 5 B         1       44.7       -6.14           5               5.52      5.07 #> 6 B         2       48.7       -8.94           5               4.19      8.67 #> # ℹ 8 more variables: standard_error <dbl>, change_se <dbl>, bound_lower <dbl>, #> #   bound_upper <dbl>, bound_lower_change <dbl>, bound_upper_change <dbl>, #> #   ci_level <lgl>, is_continuous <lgl>

title: Generate Custom ggplot2 Visualization for Longitudinal Data — generate_plot
code: generate_plot(   stats,   x_var,   y_var,   group_var = NULL,   error_type = "bar",   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   caption = NULL,   facet = NULL,   color_palette = NULL,   reference_lines = NULL,   show_sample_sizes = FALSE,   statistical_annotations = FALSE )

title: Generate Custom ggplot2 Visualization for Longitudinal Data — generate_plot
text: stats data frame containing data plotted. Must include columns specified x_var, y_var, optionally group_var, bound_lower, bound_upper error visualization. x_var string specifying column name x-axis variable. y_var string specifying column name y-axis variable. group_var string specifying column name grouping variable. error_type string specifying error type. Use "bar" error bars "band" ribbons. xlab string x-axis label. ylab string y-axis label. title string plot title. subtitle string plot subtitle. caption string plot caption. facet list specifying faceting variables. Use facet_x columns facet_y rows. optional. color_palette Optional vector colors use. NULL, default ggplot colors used. reference_lines List reference line specifications. element list components: value, axis ("x" "y"), color, linetype, size. show_sample_sizes Logical. TRUE, adds sample size annotations. statistical_annotations Logical. TRUE, adds p-values significance.

title: Generate Custom ggplot2 Visualization for Longitudinal Data — generate_plot
text: ggplot object representing visualization.

title: Generate Custom ggplot2 Visualization for Longitudinal Data — generate_plot
code: library(ggplot2) data <- data.frame(   x = rep(1:10, each = 2),   mean_value = c(1:10, 2:11),   group = rep(c("A", "B"), 10),   bound_lower = c(0.8 * (1:10), 1:10),   bound_upper = c(1.2 * (1:10), 2:11),   is_continuous = TRUE )  # Create a plot with error bands plot <- generate_plot(   stats = data,   x_var = "x",   y_var = "mean_value",   group_var = "group",   error_type = "band",   xlab = "Time",   ylab = "Measurement",   title = "Example Plot" ) print(plot)

what: Create Longitudinal Plots for Observed and Change Values — lplot
title: Create Longitudinal Plots for Observed and Change Values — lplot
text: Generates flexible plots longitudinal data, showing either observed values, change baseline, . Supports grouping faceting.

title: Create Longitudinal Plots for Observed and Change Values — lplot
code: lplot(   df,   form,   facet_form = NULL,   cluster_var = "subject_id",   baseline_value = "baseline",   xlab = "visit",   ylab = "measure",   ylab2 = "measure change",   title = "Observed Values",   title2 = "Change from Baseline",   subtitle = "",   subtitle2 = "",   caption = "",   caption2 = "",   plot_type = "obs",   error_type = "bar",   color_palette = NULL,   clinical_mode = FALSE,   treatment_colors = NULL,   confidence_interval = NULL,   show_sample_sizes = FALSE,   visit_windows = NULL,   theme = NULL,   publication_ready = FALSE,   statistical_annotations = FALSE,   reference_lines = NULL )

title: Create Longitudinal Plots for Observed and Change Values — lplot
text: df data frame containing data plotted. form formula specifying variables x-axis, grouping, y-axis. Format: y ~ x | group. facet_form formula specifying variables faceting. Format: facet_y ~ facet_x. Default NULL. cluster_var character string specifying name cluster variable grouping within subjects (typically participant subject ID). baseline_value baseline value x variable, used calculate changes. categorical x variables, treated level. continuous x variables, treated numeric value. xlab Label x-axis. ylab Label y-axis observed values plot. ylab2 Label y-axis change values plot. title Title observed values plot. title2 Title change values plot. subtitle Subtitle observed values plot. subtitle2 Subtitle change values plot. caption Caption observed values plot. caption2 Caption change values plot. plot_type Type plot return. Options "obs" (observed values), "change" (change values), "" combined plots. error_type Type error representation. Options "bar" error bars (vertical lines showing standard error) "band" error ribbons (shaded areas around line). color_palette Optional vector colors use groups. NULL, default ggplot colors used. clinical_mode Logical. TRUE, enables clinical trial defaults (95% CI, sample sizes, clinical colors). Default FALSE. treatment_colors Character. Predefined color scheme treatments. Options: "standard" (placebo=grey, active=colors), NULL. confidence_interval Numeric. Confidence level error bounds (e.g., 0.95 95% CI). NULL, uses standard error. show_sample_sizes Logical. TRUE, shows sample sizes timepoint. visit_windows List. Named list defining visit windows grouping (e.g., list("Week 4" = c(22, 35))). theme Character. Predefined theme regulatory compliance ("fda", "ema", NULL default). publication_ready Logical. TRUE, applies publication-ready defaults (professional theme, proper typography, clean styling). statistical_annotations Logical. TRUE, adds p-values significance indicators plots. reference_lines List reference line specifications. list 'value', 'axis' ("x"/"y"), 'color', 'linetype', etc.

title: Create Longitudinal Plots for Observed and Change Values — lplot
text: ggplot2 object combination objects representing requested plots.

title: Create Longitudinal Plots for Observed and Change Values — lplot
code: # Example with continuous x variable df <- data.frame(   subject_id = rep(1:10, each = 3),   visit = rep(c(0, 1, 2), times = 10),   measure = rnorm(30, mean = 50, sd = 10),   group = rep(c("Treatment", "Control"), length.out = 30) ) # Plot observed values by visit and group lplot(df, measure ~ visit | group, baseline_value = 0,        cluster_var = "subject_id")   # Example with categorical x variable df2 <- data.frame(   subject_id = rep(1:10, each = 3),   visit = rep(c("baseline", "month1", "month2"), times = 10),   measure = rnorm(30, mean = 50, sd = 10),   group = rep(c("Treatment", "Control"), length.out = 30) ) # Plot both observed and change values lplot(df2, measure ~ visit | group, baseline_value = "baseline",       cluster_var = "subject_id", plot_type = "both",       title = "Treatment Response", title2 = "Change from Baseline")   # Clinical trial example with CDISC variables clinical_data <- data.frame(   USUBJID = rep(paste0("001-", sprintf("%03d", 1:20)), each = 4),   AVISITN = rep(c(0, 1, 2, 3), times = 20),   AVAL = rnorm(80, mean = c(50, 48, 45, 42), sd = 8),   TRT01P = rep(c("Placebo", "Drug A", "Drug B"), length.out = 80) )  # Clinical mode with automatic CDISC handling lplot(clinical_data, AVAL ~ AVISITN | TRT01P,        cluster_var = "USUBJID", baseline_value = 0,       clinical_mode = TRUE, plot_type = "both",       title = "Clinical Trial Results")

what: Parse Formula Components for Longitudinal Plotting — parse_formula
title: Parse Formula Components for Longitudinal Plotting — parse_formula
text: Parses R formula object constituent components use longitudinal plotting functions. function extracts variables plotting observed values changes time, optional grouping faceting specifications.

title: Parse Formula Components for Longitudinal Plotting — parse_formula
code: parse_formula(formula)

title: Parse Formula Components for Longitudinal Plotting — parse_formula
text: formula R formula object. formula can following forms: y ~ x (simple x-y relationship) y ~ x | group (grouping) y ~ x | group ~ facet (grouping single facet) y ~ x | group ~ facet1 + facet2 (grouping multiple facets)

title: Parse Formula Components for Longitudinal Plotting — parse_formula
text: list four components: y: character string, dependent variable name (e.g., measure value) x: character string, independent variable name (typically time visit) group: character string NULL, grouping variable name specified facets: character vector NULL, faceting variable name(s) specified

title: Parse Formula Components for Longitudinal Plotting — parse_formula
text: function processes formula components following order: Extracts y-variable (dependent variable) left-hand side first '~' Extracts x-variable (typically time/visit) '|' right-hand side present, extracts grouping variable '|' present, extracts faceting variables second '~' Multiple faceting variables separated '+'. function designed work continuous categorical x-variables, supporting flexible plotting capabilities zzlongplot package.

title: Parse Formula Components for Longitudinal Plotting — parse_formula
code: # Simple longitudinal measurement parse_formula(score ~ visit) #> $y #> [1] "score" #>  #> $x #> [1] "visit" #>  #> $group #> NULL #>  #> $facets #> NULL #>   # With treatment group parse_formula(score ~ visit | treatment) #> $y #> [1] "score" #>  #> $x #> [1] "visit" #>  #> $group #> [1] "treatment" #>  #> $facets #> NULL #>   # With treatment group and site facet parse_formula(score ~ visit | treatment ~ site) #> $y #> [1] "score" #>  #> $x #> [1] "visit" #>  #> $group #> [1] "treatment" #>  #> $facets #> [1] "site" #>   # With treatment group and multiple facets parse_formula(score ~ visit | treatment ~ site + gender) #> $y #> [1] "score" #>  #> $x #> [1] "visit" #>  #> $group #> [1] "treatment" #>  #> $facets #> [1] "site"   "gender" #>

title: Create Multi-Panel Publication Figure — publication_panels
text: plots List ggplot objects combine. labels Character vector panel labels (e.g., c("", "B", "C")). layout Character string specifying layout: "horizontal", "vertical", "grid". ncol Integer. Number columns grid layout. nrow Integer. Number rows grid layout. shared_legend Logical. fig <- publication_panels(   plots = list(p1, p2),    labels = c("A", "B"),   layout = "horizontal" )  # Save the combined figure save_publication(fig, "figure1.pdf", journal = "nature", column_type = what: Flexible Plotting of Observed and Change Values with Grouping and Faceting — zzlongplot-package
title: Flexible Plotting of Observed and Change Values with Grouping and Faceting — zzlongplot-package
text: functions provide flexible framework generating observed change plots using data frame, accommodating continuous categorical variables x-axis. handle baseline (baseline_value) specification, grouping, faceting. version allows user return either observed plot, change plot, combined side--side using patchwork package.

title: Flexible Plotting of Observed and Change Values with Grouping and Faceting — zzlongplot-package
text: compute_stats: Computes summary statistics observed change values, adapting continuous categorical x-axis variables. generate_plot: Dynamically generates ggplot objects based whether x-axis continuous categorical, supports error representation (bars ribbons), faceting. parse_formula: Parses formula extract dependent, independent, grouping, faceting variables. lplot: Combines functionality helper functions produce final plots combined plots specified.
